content: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) is a government agency responsible for regulating and supervising the financial services industry in Australia. It is not a corporation. It is an independent Commonwealth government body established under the Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act 2001 (ASIC Act). The ASIC Act provides the legal framework for the regulation of the Australian financial services industry, including the securities, derivatives, and credit sectors. The ASIC is responsible for the administration of the Corporations Act, which regulates the registration and operation of companies in Australia. The ASIC also has the power to enforce the law, including through the use of fines and criminal charges, and to take action to protect consumers and investors.
